div.p: I walked up the hill to see the Sun rise— There was a thin border of cloud at the horizon, intercepting the first sunbeam; then a strip of clear sky from which his effulgence radiated for a transient moment, and then a thick body of cloud extending all over the sky, under which he disappeared, and was no more seen this day— I allowed myself but 20 minutes of morning walk and before I got back to my table there was a sprinkling drop by drop of rain over my head. It increased to a moderate calm steady rain which continued the whole day till Evening when it freshened to a North eastern breeze and copious showers— I rode morning and evening to and from meeting. Mr Lunt preached in the morning from Luke 7.47. [“]Wherefore, I say unto thee, Her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much; but to whom little is forgiven, the same loveth little”— This is a mysterious part of the personal history of Christ— It follows immediately after the performance of many of his most stupendous miracles—the healing of the centurions servant— The raising from the dead of the widow’s son; and the answer to the messengers from John the baptist with the enquiry, art thou he that should come— After all this, a Pharisee invites him to his table—and while there; a woman, Luke says, a Sinner came in with a box of precious ointment, with which she anointed the feet of Jesus, kissing them and wiping them with her hair— The pharisee secretly taxes Jesus with keeping bad company, and of course being no prophet but an impostor. Jesus detecting his suspicions, tells him the parable of the two debtors and makes him acknowledge that the debtor to whom the most was forgiven will love the most—then compares the woman’s kindness to him with that of the pharisee himself; declares that of the woman much the best; and then because she loved much, her sins, which were many, were forgiven— Here are many sins forgiven for personal adulation; and the kindness of the pharisee roughly buffeted because it was not so obsequious as that of the woman— The other three Apostles tell the story with entirely different circumstances.— With them Simon is not a pharisee, but a leper— The woman is Mary, the sister of Martha and of Lazarus.— She is not mentioned as a sinner, nor are her sins forgiven; but Judas the Traitor, blames her for wasting the precious ointment, and she is justified by Jesus— This Mary passes somewhat dubiously for Mary Magdalen, but Luke does not name her. Mr Lunt was severe upon the pharisee. So is Massillon— I do not exactly see why— Mr Lunt administered the communion, and prayed for Mrs Lee, who died of a Typhus fever this afternoon. She was the daughter of the late Mrs Anthony W. Baxter who died last Winter. A family sadly broken up— Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from 1. Thessalonians 5:23 [“]And the very God of Peace sanctify you wholly: And I pray God your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.”— He detained the members of the Church and read the Letter of invitation from the church at Jamaica plains, to the ordination of Revd. Joseph H. Allen the 18th. He proposed me as the delegate to go with him which was voted.

The rain continued till after I rose this morning and the thermometer having risen to 56 there was thick fog, and lightening without thunder. In the course of the morning the sky cleared away. I am compelled to surrender the hours before breakfast to my preparations for the west, with drawing them from the service of bodily exercise and planting. Yet my progress in the labour before me is so slow that I shall certainly not be ready for the pledged address at Dedham—the Lecture at Springfield and the Discourse at Cincinnati—besides the unexpected and sudden calls to speak, which keep me upon the rack— Last evening and this morning I wrote two Letters to Alexander Hay, one as chairman of a Committee of 50 citizens from a meeting of Friends of Liberty at Pittsburgh Pennsylvania, and the other as Mayor of the City of Pittsburgh—both being invitations to me to visit that place on my way to or from Cincinnati.— A gentleman beggar by the name of Francis Sanderson paid me a transient visit. Isaac H. Adams dined with us, and assisted my granddaughter Mary Louisa in making up the Memorial of my July tour to Canada, and the Falls of Niagara—in many respects the most memorable period of my life— It consists of the Newspaper reports of the complimentary receptions which I met at Saratoga—Ogdensburgh; the Falls, Buffalo, Rochester, Canandaigua, Auburn, Syracuse, Utica, Herkimer, Little-falls, Schenectady, Albany and Pittsfield; which I pray God may not have turned my head. I have gathered the articles containing the notices of my progress—the addresses made to me and my answers, and now have the slips pasted into an old book for Wedgwood’s copying press, which I have had these 50 years and never used— Among my troubles now is the multitude of Letters that I receive from day to day and have neither leisure, time, nor even often the ability to answer— This day 1. from Lysander Spooner, with a pamphlet upon Constitutional Law, relative to credit, currency and Banking. 2 From Theodore S. Fay U.S. Secretary of Legation at Berlin, 13. August 1843. with an enclosure from John D. Hiester, and 3 other papers relating to the claim of Dr Flügel, U.S. Consul at Leipzig, 3. From T. A. Howard Rockville, Indiana 23. Septr. 1843. with perplexing enquiries concerning periodical journals. Howard was a worthy democratic member of the 26th. Congress 1. Session, from Indiana. 4. From Samuel Howard, and 2 others—Committee of Clay club. N. 2 New-York, Switzerland County Indiana 12. Septr. 1843. asking my opinion on a curious contested election question. I cannot answer these Letters. I called this afternoon at Mr Josiah Brigham’s shop to see him, but he was gone to Weymouth— At my son’s request I endorsed his note for 2400 dollars.

Mr Brigham called on me this morning and I told him that having found it necessary to set out upon my journey to Cincinnati earlier than I had intended, I wished to change the day for my address to the inhabitants of Norfolk County, and of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, from Thursday the 26th. of this month to Tuesday the 24th.— And I requested him to give notice of this change to the other members of the Committee; and in the Newspapers of the District, which he very cheerfully promised to do. He thought the hour we had agreed upon was 11. in the morning, and I now agreed to fix that as the hour; but 10 was the hour upon which we had agreed, and I should not have consented to change it— I have a fearful weight upon my mind to prepare at once for Dedham, Springfield and Cincinnati, to keep my Diary in the current of time, and not to neglect entirely my correspondence— I receive so many Letters, and upon subjects so multifarious, that even the memory of receiving many of them escapes me, and I propose now to endorse and file them first chronologically; and alphabetically at the close of each month— I answered last Night and this morning Letters from judge Burnet and professor O. M. Mitchel of Cincinnati; promising if practicable to reach that city by the 6th. of November; the 7th. being the day named by Mr Mitchel for the ceremony. I wrote also. 1. to John B. Kirkham of Springfield apprizing him, that the day of my departure from home is changed from the 1st. of the next to the 25th of the present month, when I hope to reach Springfield in time to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at that place. 2. to John F. Lamb, at Frankford near Philadelphia, declining a renewed invitation to deliver a Lecture there. 3. To Charles J. Ingersoll, Philadelphia, who has twice transmitted to me these invitations to lecture at Frankford.— I return his courtesy with a lot of the same article. In political intercourse it may often be our duty to respect a man whom we cannot esteem; and in the encounter of partizan hostility we must make large allowance for the possible injustice of our own prejudices and prepossessions. I received this day Letters 1. From T. A. Howard, Rockville Indiana 23 Septr 1843. Another political adversary, asking good offices for a literary institution. Can I deny, or withhold them? 2. From T. B. Wakeman—New-York—with a printed circular notice of the 11th. annual Fair of the American Institute at New-York and a skein of black sewing silk. 3. From Albert Wright, superintendent of common schools, Washington County, New-York, 28 Septr 1843. who is to write upon physical education, and asks for my experiences— How shall I answer him?— There was this afternoon a very sudden thunder gust; and a beautiful double rainbow. Walk up the hill— Mrs Charles and the two Louisa’s.

I devoted this day to labour and made my record of yesterday before breakfast— I thought I should have a long morning for writing, but Mr Curtis my Co-Executor of the Will of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston with Mrs Alicia Boylston his widow came, and informed me, that last Wednesday Mrs Boylston, who resides with her son at Providence Rhode-Island had a severe fit of palsy, which may be hourly expected to terminate fatally. That her right side is wholly impotent and she is speechless, though still in full possession of her mind. The event of her decease will impose upon him and me immediate and complicated duties, which will require our immediate and most assiduous attention— We read carefully the Will over together. The three Co-Executors are also constituted joint Trustees for the management of the Estate, real and personal, for the payment of sundry annuities, rents and profits, and of sundry bequests to take effect on the decease of Mrs Boylston— The Trust is almost a perpetuity, and the will requires that on the decease of either of the Trustees the survivors shall nominate a person to be appointed by the judge of Probate as the third Trustee, so that there may be always three, during the continuance of the Trust— A life estate was given to Mrs Boylston, in all the real Estate, but the moment after her decease the Trust attaches to it all. We agreed 1. That in the event of Mrs Boylston’s decease, we must immediately nominate a third Trustee for the appointment by the judge of probate, and that it shall be my Son, if he will consent. 2. That from the moment of Mrs Boylston’s decease accounts must be opened by the Trusts with all the Estates specifically devised, and with all the annuitants and beneficiaries 3.— That the option must be offered to Dr Ward Nicholas Boylston, to occupy the Princeton Estate, and to Thomas Boylston to occupy the Roxbury Estate; in which case the management of them will devolve upon themselves respectively; and if they decline occupying them they must do it in writing to be kept of record in the probate Office. 4. That an inventory should be taken of all the property, with which the Trustees will be chargeable from the day of Mrs Boylston’s decease—and a list of all the persons to whom they will have bequests or annuities to pay. 5. That they must take possession of all papers relating to the Execution of the will or the trusts, which have been hitherto in the possession of Mrs Boylston— Mr Curtis has received also from Petty Vaughan, by the Acadia, yesterday arrived one copy of the bond to be executed by us which he left with me. The other copy is to come by the Great Western. I promised to go next Monday to Boston, with an account for settlement between the Administrations of Thomas Boylston and Moses Gill, of which Mr Curtis promised to give notice to Mr George Fuller— I called at Mr Brigham’s shop, but he was gone to Boston.— I left at the Aurora Office a notice for publication to-morrow.

Though I intermitted the morning excursion before Sunrise, and devoted the whole day to labour I was yet unable to complete my record before breakfast, and then the hours slip’d away: the noon bell rang, and my page was scarcely finished when I was called to dinner. The Quincy Aurora of this day has the notice that I left at the Office yesterday, that I will address the People of the County of Norfolk and of the 8th. Congressional district of Massachusetts on Tuesday the 24th. of this Month at 10. A.M. at Dedham— There is also a separate notification by the Norfolk County Committee to the same effect— I called at Mr Brigham’s shop, and agreed with him about the hour, and said it would be important to me to come home that day to dinner to have half the day to prepare for my departure the next morning. I then called in at the Quincy Patriot Office and requested the republication in that paper on Saturday of my notification in this day’s Aurora; which was promised.— Green the Editor of the Patriot is convalescent from a Typhus fever, but was not at the office— On my way, finding the grave-yard open, I went in, and saw the improvements they are making there. A strong cemented wall, with an iron gate and railing have been recently placed as a fence fronting the road—the old tombstone of the parish ministers has been rebuilt by the Ladies of Quincy, and the range of excavated tombs, with the names of their owners is carried round 3. sides of the square— But not a trace is to be found either of John Quincy or of Anna Fiske his mother—nor of John Quincy’s wife, all my ancestors. My Son was there with Deacon Spear; consulting about some inscription; and some improvement upon the family tomb, which belonged to my father, and where his remains, and those of my mother were at first deposited— My Son came home with me, and I proposed to him in the event of Mrs Boylston’s decease, that we should nominate him for appointment by the judge of probate as the third trustee in place of Mrs Boylston, to execute the trusts created by Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will— He asked my advice, and I advised and earnestly intreated him to accept the trust. He read over the Will and made no objection to my proposal.— He brought me a deed of a small strip of land for ten dollars to be conveyed to Ebenezer Adams, which I and my wife signed and sealed— I closed Letters to Miss Aricartha Miller at New-York, declining to deliver a Lecture; and to the Revd. Henry Jackson of New-Bedford in answer to enquiries about my eyes but I found not one half hour to write a Letter for this day— After dinner I read some pages of Bailly and some pages of Adam Smith’s History of Astronomy without ascertaining as I wanted the origin of the existing Zodiac, and Grecian Constellations— I bethought myself of Dupuis’s Origine de tous les cultes and supposing I might find there what I wanted, I borrowed the 11 volumes from the town Library and they engaged me till day light failed— Charles and his wife were here till the curfew, and I wrote till the clock struck midnight.

Another day of intense and agonizing labour dissatisfied with my own work and disheartened All confidence in myself lost and ready to despair of assistance, whence alone it can come— Major Thomas Adams came, and asked me for a Letter of introduction to governor Lincoln, whom he proposes to visit, to invite him to come and address the whigs of Quincy, upon electioneering topics. He said Mr Choate the U.S. Senator had advised him last week, at Dedham to apply to Governor Lincoln; and upon Adams’s objecting that he thought Mr Lincoln would not come, answered “yes he will.” How this came to be known to Mr Choate, he did not say; perhaps he assumed to say it without authority, to escape from the importunity of Mr Adams, to prevail on him to come and discourse electioneering politics to the whigs of Quincy. I told Mr Adams that I would give him a Letter of introduction to Mr Lincoln. Mr. Robinson the episcopal clergyman of this place, Mr Howe the Minister of that church at Roxbury, with Mrs Robinson and Mrs. Howe, with Messrs. Snow, Cutler, Bent, and another, all episcopal ministers, paid us a morning visit all together— They are here at an annual convention of ministers of that church, I believe recently instituted, and this is one of many indications of the aspiring and domineering spirit of the clergy of that church, who at this time are taking a desparate lurch backwards into the arms of the Pope— We were all invited to spend this evening at Mr Lunt’s—but my wife, Mary Catherine, her daughter Mary Louisa, and Louisa C Smith are all afflicted with severe colds, and my time is so totally absorbed in the work before me that we all sent excuses— I ransacked Goguet, Bailly and Dupuis for the origin of the Zodiac, Constellations and Milky way. I consulted also the Abbé Banier’s Mythology, and Fables of the Antients explained from history, and this reading swallowed up the day till dark— Then after half an hour for tea, I sat down by lamplight, and wrote till half past 11. wrote without intermission, driving like Jehu till the two pages for the day were completed. Trash which I shall not have assurance to deliver, and probably not even to print. Mr John A. Green, came this afternoon and took my acknowledgment and that of my wife to the deed of about 1200 square feet of land to Ebenezer Adams which we executed yesterday

The whole hemisphere was covered with watery clouds, excepting a small strip of clear sky along the eastern horizon of the width of one third of the Sun’s-disk; the cloud ranging over it and bordering the horizon beneath it— The Sun was therefore about one third risen, when his first beam was visible; and when full risen the central third part of his disk shone bright, while the upper and nether sections of it were beclouded. As he rose there fell a few drops of rain which immediately held up, and a calm cloudy day succeeded till about 4. in the afternoon when it began to rain very gently and continued with light and scanty showers all the evening— Charles’s two Sons, came from school at Hingham. Isaac H. Adams was here this forenoon and my Son spent the Evening with us.— I went up the hill at Mrs Charles’s request to settle the notice to be given to William C Johnson of the time when he may expect me to arrive at Utica, on my way to Cincinnati— He had intimated a disposition to go with me, if I should desire it— Mrs Charles wrote to him about ten days since, inviting him in my name to go, and has received his answer that he will go— She is now to write to him that he may expect me at Utica on Friday the 27th. of this month, and must be ready to start with me at moment’s warning any time after Thursday the 26th. I had no interruptions this day, and yet wrote not one line of my discourse, the work that hangs most heavily on my Spirits— In the historical summary of the Science, which I have introduced into the address, I have come to the period of the Arabian Caliphs, and am preparing for the transition to the modern Astronomy to Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Galileo, Descartes and Kepler the precursors of Newton, upon all of whom I must bestow a transient glance— Smith’s History of Astronomy, furnishes some hints, but absorbs much time— For the Arabians not having Ockley’s history of the Saracens which I want, at hand I must put up with the 52d. chapter of Gibbon, which I hunted up, and pored over— I plunged also further into the turbid anti-Christian stream of Dupuis, and recurred to Dacier’s life of Pythagoras in the first volume of the Bibliotheque des Anciens Philosophes— This mass of heterogeneous reading absorbed the day, and bore with such pressure on the brain, that when evening came I was compelled by overpowering lassitude to desist—looked with my granddaughter Mary Louisa into Bode’s Uranographia for sundry stars which I see every clear morning, and which I now find are in the body of the great Bear—and lost my day. John A. Green Editor of the Quincy Patriot, told me that he attended a convention of the Liberty party last week at Dedham. That they agreed upon an address to the People, which would be published in the Patriot as it is, and that they ordered 2000 copies of it to be printed separately with my Letter to the Bangor Committee on the back of the sheet.

Stormy Night, and day. Doctor Convers Francis, Professor of Pulpit eloquence and the pastoral care at Harvard University preached, this morning from Revelation 2.7. “He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches.—[”] There is something so original, in Dr Francis’s manner of treating his subject that I cannot follow the links of connection between his text and his discourse— There was commentary upon the words of the text, the meanin of which is rather obscure—he finally expounded them to mean a Message from the holy spirit to the Christian churches— The argument was intricate; and its drift not very obvious till it came suddenly to its conclusion—namely that whatever might be the doctrines preached in the name of the spirit none were genuine but such as led directly to the improvement of mankind in practical morality, virtue and benevolence— I did not expect that this would be the peculiar axiom, drawn from that text— Neither could I perceive the flaw in the thread— The first hymn which the Doctor gave out to be sung was 536. of Mr Lunt’s Christian Psalter— My hymn for sabbath morning.— There are in that collection 22. Psalms and hymns of my composition; but the exultation of heart that I felt on hearing it read and sung as a part of the devotions of the day was preposterous and I own sinful vanity. I pray God to suppress in me, all pride at any manifestations of human applause that I may have recently receive, and to dispose me in the sincerity of my Soul, to see in them only lessons of humiliation— Dr Francis dined with us and preached this afternoon, from 1. Corinthians 15.10. [“]But, by the grace of God I am what I am”; another text which I should not have selected as peculiarly copious of instruction. But perhaps the perfection of the art of preaching consists in extracting a large nut from a small shell. The Doctor’s lesson was that all Christians should consider themselves to be what they are, by the grace of God; and it is doubtless the duty and the joy of a virtuous man, to live with God always in his thoughts Dr Francis gave notice that from this time for the winter the morning hour of meeting will be half past 10. and the afternoon a quarter before 2— My most urgent labour necessarily lags behind— I consulted Sotheby’s Georgics, for the line. Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas. Tis Book 2. verse 490.

I was at last forced to lay aside for the day my most pressing occupation to make up my accounts as Administrator de bonis non, with the will annexed of Thomas Boylston, for the judge of Probate— And an Account with George Fuller, Administrator on the Estates of the two Moses Gills— To complete the settlement there is also an account with the Executors of Ward N. Boylston to be made up, but that may be deferred to another day.— The morning till 10 was consumed in preparing the two Accounts, and then I went in to Boston, with Louisa C. Smith, my Son, and my grand daughter Mary-Louisa.— Called at Robert C. Winthrop’s, but he was not at home— At the probate-Office, where I met Mr George Fuller. I exhibited my Account N. 3. as Administrator of Thomas Boylston, to the judge; and I had now the Office copy of my account N. 2. settled in November 1839. Neither the original nor record of which could be found at the office at the Courts which I have attended within the last year; and the want of which has hitherto prevented the final settlement of the account with Fuller.— The Account with him and the Account of Administration were inspected by the judge and by Mr Fuller, who agreed to settle the account with him, as drawn up by me; but afterwards asked me to let him take the account with him, to which I assented and he took it— I met Solomon Lincoln the U.S. Marshal who piloted me to the Office of Mr Bassett the Clerk of the U.S. Courts, where I borrowed a copy of the Acts of Congress of the last Session. At my Son’s Office I met Mr Curtis, who informed me that Mrs Alicia Boylston died at Providence R.I. at 2. O’Clock yesterday afternoon— Mr Sherman Leland the judge of probate for the County of Norfolk keeps an Office in Boston, and at our request came to Charles’s. We presented an application to him nominating Charles Francis Adams for his appointment as the third Trustee under Ward N. Boylston’s will in the place of his widow, now deceased— The judge said he would hold an adjourned Court at Roxbury next Saturday, and then make the appointment— Mr Curtis had the second copy of the bond of indemnity to Petty Vaughan, received by the Great Western arrived on Saturday at New-York. I took it with me— I met De Grand in State Street, and he went with me to N. 33. Chatham Street John D. and Moses Williams, where I ordered a cask of Claret and a cask of Teneriffe wine. Returning we went into the new-Merchants Exchange, where I met Mr Green the past and future Postmaster— At 1. we rendezvous’d at Mr James H. Fosters, and came home to dine. Charles’s sons John and Charles dined with us, and afterwards went to Hingham. He was here this evening.

The sky was not wholly cleared off this morning so that I could not see the Sunrise. I was able therefore to devote the morning till breakfast to the Diary, and just finished it in time— I may therefore lay it down as a general rule that rising at 4. I can close the record of the day before, to breakfast at 8. and I can do no more— But then the disposable part of the day is gone— I hoped I should have a long day for progress on the Astronomical Discourse; and leisure for my correspondence. I was bitterly disappointed— Orin P. Bacon, Postmaster at the Neponset Village with his Uncle Asa Bacon, an inhabitant of the State of Vermont, and his Son Washington Asa Bacon, a settler at Detroit in the State of Michigan, paid me, together a morning visit— I went into my garden to visit my trees and plant some whole peaches and pears, nuts and acorns, but was called back to Mr Brigham to agree upon arrangements for the meeting at Dedham this day fortnight when I am to address the People of the County of Norfolk, and of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— Mr Brigham will go with me—to start at 1/2 past 7. A.M—reach Dedham at 9. Hold the meeting at 10. and return home to dine immeditely after the address— We agreed also upon other details of arrangement. I went a second time into my garden and Nursery, and was recalled again to a visit from Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, and the Revd. Doctor Pierce of Brookline— A visit of courtesy and civility— Coll. Perkins is close upon four score— My acquaintance with him commenced at the ordination of Henry Ware at Hingham in September 1787. Since which he has been prosperous in life and is now one of the wealthiest men in this country— I finally planted my pears and peaches promiscuously in a row, by the gate between the garden and Nursery, but without order or selection of seeds.— The morning was gone and I was called to dinner— It was scarcely over when Mr Cummings of the Quincy Lyceum came to enquire, if I could deliver a Lecture there this day fortnight at 1/2 past 7. in the evening— I told him I was engaged to deliver a Lecture, precisely at that time, at Springfield 100 miles from this place— As there is no day between this and then, which would suit the Quincy Lyceum, Mr Cummings thanked me for my former services to them, and released me from any engagement for the present Season— My Son went to Boston, and attended the funeral of Mrs Alicia Boylston at Mount Auburn and returned home to dine— John Lane Boylston, his two sons and three daughters, and Mr. Curtis were there— The extreme pressure upon my time prevented me from attending; much to my regret— Charles brought home and gave me a Boston Morning Post of this day containing a Letter from Duff Green at London dated the 18th. of September last, somewhat concerning me, and which I am to consider whether I should notice it or not. The print being too small for my eyes, I took it, with my grand-daughter Mary Louisa into my Library, and she read it for me.

Rising an hour later than my time, precludes the making up of my record before breakfast, and that throws it back upon the noon tide bell; and excepting the walk up hill to see the rising sun, and the visits to the wood house I superseded all athletic exercise. I received a Letter from Mr Henry Clay, with a kind and cordial invitation to Kentucky,

and to Ashland his house, on the occasion of my approaching tour to Cincinnati— And the invitation is extended equally to Mrs Adams— I receive it with a full sense of the generous and friendly feeling of Mr Clay; but under equal embarrassment whether to accept or to decline it— I had intended not to protract my journey beyond the absolute necessity required for the performance of the duty which I have engaged to perform; and that becomes more formidable as I approach the day of performance. Even now it brings me to the borders of distraction— There are numerous reasons why I should not step beyond the State of Ohio, and my deliberate judgment is that I should adhere to that determination— Yet there are considerations of great weight prompting to my acceptance of the invitations to Kentucky, and especially that of Mr Clay— I must wait for Counsel.— Deacon Spear and his son Charles were here with his brother in Law, Mr Crowell from Londonderry in New Hampshire— The Deacon left with me plans of two lots of woodland, parcels of the 600 acres and adjoining my lots there, which Mr Josiah Bass junr offers for sale—with an appraisement by Lewis Bass high above its real marketable value.— After dinner we had a visit from Mr and Mrs Loring of Hingham— Mr Loring urged me warmly to deliver an address to the whigs at Boston upon the public Lands; about which he said the People were very much in the dark.— But I have already undertaken more than I can perform.— This afternoon I undertook to gather and pack up in chests all my files of Letters received since the 3d. of March 1829. when I retired from the President’s house to Meridian hill— I packed in the rough chest received last Spring from Washington, all the files from 1829. to 1837. inclusive; and they fill the chest— They are yet not complete, and need a thorough new packing; for which I hope to have time and leisure and resolution hereafter— The files from 1838 to this time will require a second chest. Mean time my day was consumed my spirits worn out and my soul cast down to the nervous affections of second childhood— An alarm of inflammation in the eyes, suddenly supervening yesterday and this day aggravates my anticipations; and the necessity of suppressing my emotions before my family, does not alleviate them— Charles and his wife were here this evening— I gave Abby, a card portrait autograph, such as one I gave last week to Mrs Sarah Morton— I snatched a half an hour to read some pages of Dr Bowditch’s Article on Modern Astronomy, in the North American Review and wrote two pages by setting up till Midnight.
Sun rose 6.9. clear, fog below. Fahrenheit 36.

A tolerable night’s rest, that is to say of four hours dissipated most of my nervous fantasies, but not the soreness and inflammation of my eyes; but my washing and dressing with making of my fire, providing my chamber with firewood for the day, and tripping up the hill to see the sun rise occupied a large hour and a half of the morning.— The sun rose crystal clear and Charles house on the hill was surrounded by an atmosphere equally clear; while all the low lands around, and my own house were covered with a thick fog— Returning from my walk my fingers were pinched with cold so that I could not write— I read therefore, part of Dr Bowditch’s Article upon modern Astronomy in the North American Review of April 1825. without finishing it— A valuable Article to which I must if possible again recur— But this delayed my diary page of yesterday till dinner time— My wife, Louisa C. Smith, Charles and his wife went to Boston, and returned home to dine— Mean while I had visits from Mr John P. Robinson the Episcopalian Minister of Christ Church in this town; with Mr Wells, teacher of a school at South Boston and eleven of his boys— After that Friend Crane of Canton, a man born in 1776. and to whom the Christian name was given in pursuance of a resolution long premeditated by his father— He came to see me from curiosity merely. Towards Sunset Coll. Josiah Quincy junr called; having come out from Boston to look at the beautiful place which has been desolate all this summer because there is too much solitude at Quincy for his wife. His son Samuel was with him— My Son brought a bond to be given by him to the judge of probate for the county of Norfolk, and to which Mr Nathaniel Curtis are to be the sureties, and myself, upon his appointment by the judge, as the third Trustee, for the execution of the Trusts created by Ward Nicholas Boylston’s will in the place of his widow; now deceased— Charles and myself signed and sealed the bond, and Louisa C. Smith, and my son John’s widow, Mary Catherine signed as witnesses—which they did also to my execution of the two copies of the bond of indemnity and release which have been received from him recently by the Acadia and the Great Western— I continue my endeavours for the assortment of my papers; but receive daily more Letters than I am able to answer— I have this day one from S. P. Hildreth and 25. a Committee of the Inhabitants of Marietta in the State of Ohio 3. Octr. 1843. an invitation to visit that place on my tour to Cincinnati—and one from John A. Watkins, Rodney, Mississippi 19. Septr. 1843. a very earnest exhortation to me to prevail upon Congress to erect a monument to George Washington, to cost half a million of dollars.— My work upon the Astronomical Address was postponed as usual from hour to hour till after the curfew and then the heavy drowsy head and smarting eyes so languidly performed their offices that it was with extreme effort I got through one-page devoted to Kepler.
An uninterrupted and yet an inefficient day—
Charles went to Boston and returned to dine—

Great part of the day was consumed in packing up my files of Letters from 1838 to 1842 inclusive in one of the rough hewn chests from Washington, which they fill.— All the files from 1829. to the close of the last year are now packed in these two chests but it would require a week of time to repack them in perfect order, and they might very advantageously be decimated for preservation, and nine in ten of them committed to the flames. I found upon the files sundry papers which I have long been searching for in vain Among them the bond of indemnity and release to Petty Vaughan, which has been so long missing: five of my son Charles’s quarterly accounts, and the statement of the Gill claim on the Administration of Thomas Boylston’s Estate, which I drew up in June 1839. and which had so unaccountably disappeared.— I received this day Letters 1. from Samuel N. Sweet. 7. Octr. Rochester New-York, with a narrative of my visit to Rochester, by a youth named John C. Chumasero, and some enquiry of my opinion concerning a book upon elocution of which he is the author and presented me with a copy when I was there— 2. From Hiram Teal and Co. 30 Septr. 1843. La Fayette Indiana, with enquiries concerning a petition to Congress which they say they sent to me last winter, but of which I have no recollection. 3. from Edmund Quincy, Dedham 12. Octr. an exceedingly cordial invitation to his house on the 20th. when I am to address my Constituents of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, in that town— 4. from the late judge John Davis. Boston 12. Octr: enquiries and remarks upon Astronomy, with much highly interesting matter— All these Letters require answers, but where shall I find to write them.— I finished reading this day Smith’s posthumous fragment history of Astronomy to the time of Newton, and Dr Bowditch’s Article on Modern Astronomy in the North American Review of April 1825.—both excellent summaries—the Article taking it up, where Smith leaves it, and the two forming together a complete and very useful abridgement of the history of the Science from its origin down to 1825.— Dr Bowditch confines himself to mere matter of fact; indulging far less in philosophical speculation than the man of Scotland.— Bowditch’s Review is precious for the selection of topics which the modern Astronomers have chiefly discussed; and for the list of the recent Astronomical writers whose works he recommends with favourable notice. Among them is a History of ancient Astronomy in 2. 4to. Volumes Astronomy of the middle ages in 1. and of modern Astronomy in 2. by Delambre which I have never seen— Charles brought me a message from Mr Nathaniel Curtis requesting me to prepare a Letter to Petty Vaughan to be sent with the bond of indemnity, by the Acadia Steamer the day of whose departure will be next Monday. I accordingly wrote the Letter.

The Misses Maria, and Elizabeth Rebeca Nicholson daughters of Commodore Samuel Nicholson, a naval officer of the War of Independence came from Dedham, where they reside to consult with me, concerning a claim for arrears of pay due to their father for a term of 13 Months, during which he was under arrest upon trial by a Court Martial— He was honourably acquitted of the charges, but his pay was suspended while he was under arrest and was never restored— In 1836. These Ladies petitioned Congress upon this claim Their petition was presented by William Jackson, and referred to a Committee— It was afterwards in the charge successively of John Reed and of William S. Hastings— There was another petition by their sister Mrs Rogers of New-York, for herself and them, for the same claim, and Mr Talmadge the Senator from New-York, has advocated the claim in the Senate. Theron Metcalf of Dedham drew their petition, and with it were sundry papers to support the claim which have never been returned to them— They have heard that they were mislaid and could not be found. They shewed me a copy of their petition which I read— They are I take it both of the last century and totally destitute— I advised them to prepare a new petition, referring to the former one and to the proceedings of Congress upon it. To send me the new Petition, which I promised to present and to call up the old one with its vouchers— Mr Lunt called and gave me a minute of the birth of Daniel Quincy 12 Septr. 1650. and of John Quincy, 5. April 1652 (he died 14. Augt. 1674) and of the death of Henry Adams 8. October 1646. which he took yesterday from the Boston town records. He agreed to go with me next Wednesday to the ordination of Mr Allen at Jamaica Plains— to leave here at 1/2 past 11 O’Clock A.M The council are to meet at 1 p.m. The ordination service to commence at 2. and tea after it is over— After dinner Isaac H. Adams and his Sister Mrs. Angier were here— Also Dr Fisher of Dorchester and Mr Edward Jarvis who said that they proposed to memorialize Congress, to demand a revisal of the returns of the last census especially with regard to the number of persons returned as insane. From these returns it is made to appear that there is an immense disproportion of insane persons, of the free coloured class, over every other portion of the population. The Slave-mongers are building upon it a systematic argument in support of Slavery. Mr Jarvis has published in the Boston Courier an Article, proving that the census returns have been falsified to give this appearance to the facts.— He believes that the falsification of the Document was made at the Department of State, and therefore proposes this memorial to demand the revisal of it— I told him that if they would send the memorial to me I would present it—

White frost. Chilly day. Just before meeting this morning, a Card was brought to me from French’s tavern, with the name engraved on it of Aaron Ely Hovey, with the word Mrs in pencil mark prefixed to the name, and From Washington citty D.C. underneath—and on the back of the card “Please call after church. I want to see you on particular buisness” in pencil, without signature. Mr Smith, a young man recently settled as a colleague of Dr Francis Parkman in Boston was the preacher. His morning text from Romans 1.28 [“]And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient.” After meeting I went over to French’s tavern, and enquired if there was a lady there who wished to see me— George French said yes, and shewed me to a chamber up two pair of stairs, where was a mean looking woman, in a decent mourning dress. To shew me who she was she exhibited two certificates of good character and conduct one by the name of Vinsen, and the other signed by a minister of a church at Saybook in Connecticut attesting her admission as a member of the church there in 1836. She then told me a long story of her living at Washington from 1822 to 1828. of her subsequent marriage with Mr Hovey and of their poverty and destitution— She wanted money.— I asked her if she lived with her husband? Sometimes.— But he had been for a long time unable to obtain employment— Did they live at Saybrook?— At Westport— I refused to give her money, with some expression of indignation that she, a member of the church should come here to demand money of me.— I asked if she had not written to me, making the same demand— She said she had. She asked if I would give her enough to pay her expenses back? I said not a cent—and left her.— When I got home I found Mr Smith the Minister and Mr Degrand from Boston, who dined with us. While we were at dinner Mr Grattan the British Consul came and took my acknowledgment of my signature and seal to the Bond of indemnity and release to Petty Vaughan. With him was Mr Reed, one of the late Commissioners from New Brunswick at the negotiation of the Ashburton Treaty— They declined staying to dine and Mr Grattan borrowed my cloak to return to Boston— Mr Smith’s afternoon text was from Hebrews 12.14. [“]Follow peace with all men, and holiness without which no man shall see the Lord.”— We hand company at tea and in the evening as above in the margin— Mrs Charles gave me a note to her from Mary Ann Bigelow and I received a note in pencil from Mrs Hovey.

A pattern day. When I rose, the sky was beclouded with lucid spots in the East, but about five, it began to sprinkle and rained in copious showers with short intervals the whole day and evening: Fahrenheit 52. I finished my Diary minutes just in time for breakfast, and by snatching every leisure moment, wrote 3 pages of Astronomy, to make up for the lapse of the two preceding days in which I had not written a line— And I closed the day by writing an answer to Mr Henry Clay’s invitation to visit him at Ashland, his residence in Kentucky— This is I believe the maximum of performance in writing in the space of one day for the rest of my life.— But I received with the mail this morning a letter from Mr Frye to my son, which supposing it to relate to the affairs of Mr T. B. Johnson, of no urgency, I left on my table, till evening twilight came on, when I took it up the hill and delivered it— My wife on leaving Washington to come here had left in charge with Doctor Hall Mr Johnson’s attending physician, in the event of an unfavourable change in the symptoms of Mr Johnson’s disease, to have notice of it immediately conveyed to her; and Mr Frye says that Dr. Hall, in concurrence with Dr Thomas and Mrs Smith requests him to give that notice.— I received also Letters 1. from David A. Bokee and 3 others committee of the whigs of Brooklyn, who are proposing to hear a course of political lectures this Season, and invite me to deliver the introductory. 2. from John L. Sibley—Assistant Librarian of Harvard University, making enquiries concerning the books that I have given to that Library— Also concerning the books given by my father—donations, he observes which never have been sufficiently acknowledged— He enquires also concerning the titles annexed to names in the triennial Catalogues; upon which I am not well informed. 3. from Lewis Johnson, Washington 11. Octr. 1843. with an enclosure for John Otis— My daughter Mrs John Adams has undertaken to make a copy for me of the Discourse prepared for delivery at Cincinnati on the occasion of laying the corner-stone of the Astronomical Observatory at that place. I have projected an address of 48 pages which would take 3 hours in the delivery. 45 pages of it are written, and I want at least 25 more, to fill up the Outline—but I have not the time, and must close abruptly leaving perhaps the most important part of what should be said unnoticed My wife on the advices received this day from Washington, of the dangerous state of her brother, thinks of going off immediately for Washington, and if she goes, I have promised to go with her— It disconcerts all my arrangements, but duty admits of no alternative.

Clear sky—whereupon I went up the hill and saw the Sun rise, and consequently could not finish my daily record before breakfast— Calisto was perpendicular to the horizon from my Northeastern window tail downwards, Benetnasch so far above the horizon that I assume Arcturus rose at 5. but I did not see him— At 5 the dawn is so far advanced the bright stars of the Bear herself have faded almost out of sight, and those in her paws are no longer visible.— They do not indeed properly belong to the Bear any more than Asterion or Chara.— My only domestic interruption of the day was to see the disposal of 280 bottles of common claret wine from the cask purchased last week of John D and M. Williams in my cellars.— I have taken this occasion to have the cellars themselves cleared out, which was needed; and which I have too long neglected. I had upwards of 200 of the bottles of claret deposited in the arch under west-end of the house and 6 dozen in the Arch under the East-end— In the central cellar I found 5 boxes of wines brought in 1829 from Washington, and took out of one box 12 bottles of Vin de la Nerthe packed up at Tain—choice Hermitage— I must give it away. Mr Brigham called this afternoon, and enquired from the Norfolk County Committee whether I could furnish them with a copy of the address I am to deliver at Dedham next Tuesday— I told him that would be impossible— That I have little or nothing written— That I shall have time to write little or nothing, and that a great portion of my address must and will be extemporaneous— I agonize at the thought, and it haunts me day and night.— But I said I supposed there would be reporters there from the Boston Newspapers; and they must put up with their reports; for I shall not have even time to revise them— He said he believed the Committee would employ a reporter— I told him I might perhaps be obliged to go off to Washington the day after to-morrow, in which case it will be impossible for me to deliver the address at Dedham; and if it should be so, I must rely upon the Committee to give notice to the People of the District in time to save them from being disappointed— As I lost the light of day to write, I went over the hill to Mr Lunt, and notified him that I might be prevented from going with him to morrow to the ordination at Jamaica plains— My wife seems strongly inclined to go immediately to Washington; and have promised if she goes to go with her— Mr Lunt’s father was at his house— Charles and his wife and daughter Louisa were here this evening— Their boys do not go again to Hingham.— I wrote this evening till past 11. Three pages this day; and filled my 48th. page.

div.dateline: Quincy. Wednesday 18. October 1843. Jamaica Plains. Quincy.
div.p: In the Southern aspect of my front door, I took the thermometer up the hill, and at the Northwestern corner of Charles’s house as the Sun rose it stood at 28.— The average difference between the two expositions is about 4 degrees. Returning from my Sun rise walk I met Benjamin Andrews our coachman, with the morning mail from the Post Office, in his hand.— On giving me the Letters and Newspapers, he took from his pocket a Letter addressed to Charles F. Adams, which he observed was from Washington and had a black seal— The superscription being in the hand writing of Mr Frye, I opened it and found it dated the 14th. at 7. in the evening and announced that Mr Thomas Baker Johnson, my wife’s only brother died that same evening at 10 minutes before 6. and that it would be necessary to inter his remains before any of the family could reach Washington. I wrote immediately to Mr Frye, enclosing a copy of Mr Johnson’s Will, and authorising him to do every thing necessary for its execution till I come— My wife not thinking it necessary to hasten her departure for Washington, my own arrangements remain undisturbed— Mr Richardson of Braintree was here anxious about an appropriation for the Boston Custom house, to the building of which he says he and his company have delivered by contract stone to the amount of 30000 dollars, for which they are unpaid.— Mr Lunt, came before 11. and again at half past 11. and went with me to Jamaica Plains, to attend the Ordination of Joseph Henry Allen as Pastor of the third parish in Roxbury. The Council met at the village Hall at 1. O’Clock P.M. The proceedings there were short and unanimous; and at 2. they proceeded to the meeting house where the services were performed in the following order—Voluntary—Ordination—Anthem—Introductory prayer by Revd. F. T. Gray—Selections from the Scriptures by Revd F. D. Huntington—Original hymn—Sermon by Revd Joseph Allen of Northborough, father of the youth now ordained— The text was Hebrews 13.8. [“]Jesus Christ, the same yesterday, and to day, and forever.” Original hymn— Tune Priscilla. Prayer of Ordination by Revd. Edward B. Hall of Providence R.I. Charge by Revd. Thomas Gray D.D. the Pastor of the same church who has just resigned his office. Right hand of fellowship, by Revd. John Fothergill Waterhouse Ware of Fall river: a son of Dr Henry Ware junr. recently deceased. The address to the Society, by Revd. George Putnam of Roxbury, and the concluding prayer by the Revd. Nathaniel Hall of Dorchester— Then, what is called an Ascription sung by the choir, and the benediction by the newly ordained pastor— All the services were good and well performed— A collation at the village Hall before and after the service— No other beverage but cold water and cool tea. The services closed a quarter past 5— We had called at Dr Gray’s house. Mr Lunt came home with me. We landed at 1/2 past 6. and I wrote till 11.

I asked Dr Frothingham yesterday at the council meeting whether the Steamer Hibernia had arrived. He said not, when he left Boston at Noon. While we were speaking she was landing her passengers at East-Boston wharf— Among them were Abbot Lawrence and his family— Miss Lincoln whom he left in charge of his small children whom he did not take with him was a few days since found dead in her bed. The newspapers of yesterday announce the same thing of Dr Linn, late Senator of the United States from the State of Missouri.— I received yesterday a Letter from Professor O. M. Mitchel. Cincinnati 8. October, urging for my answer to his and judge Burnet’s previous Letters of 8 September— I had answered them on the 3d. of this month—and my answer to him, with an omission of half a line, is published in this morning’s Atlas copied from a Cincinnati paper.— My answer was received on the 10th. two days after professor Mitchel had written to me to hasten it; and the Society to whom my Letters were communicated, finally fixed Thursday the 9th. of November for the ceremony instead of Tuesday the 7th. which they had first proposed— May the blessing of Heaven rest upon the destined day.— And I received this day a Letter from Louisa Staughton, Rebecca Burnet and Clarissa Davies, a Committee of Invitation of the Ladies of Cincinnati, who propose to give a Temperance tea-party, the day after the laying of the corner stone of the observatory—and they invite my attendance.— My Son came this morning with a written summary of the parts of Mr Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will which now call for the special attention of the Executors and Trustees— The judge of probate Leland has appointed him the third Trustee, in the place of the late Mrs Alicia Boylston.— He is apprehensive that some of the provisions of the Will are susceptible of exceptionable constructions, upon which it will be necessary to have the decision of the judge of probate before responsible action— There are conditional bequests to the amount of 3000 dollars to Harvard University, and 1000 to the inhabitants of the Town of Princeton, about which Letters must be written by the Trustees, and Charles has prepared a draught of a Letter to Ward Nicholas Boylston and Thomas Boylston asking their answer in writing, whether they propose to occupy any part of the Estates respectively bequeathed for their use, as by the Will they have the option to do— I approved these drafts, and asked Charles to make out a brief minute of all the points to which the Executors must attend before I go hence.— I took to the Post-Office a Letter to Hiram Teall and Co. and worked like a pack-horse to finish the astronomical Oration without success— I found John Kirk removing the fence between the garden and Orchard— After 10. O’Clock this evening I began to write an introductory paragraph to the address which I am to deliver next Tuesday at Dedham. This is all that I shall be able to prepare for that occasion. [symbols].

The Sun rose from the corner of Charles’s house directly behind the trunk of an English white oak tree. The thermometer at the Northwest corner of Charles’s house, stood at the same point as at my South front door— I received this morning Letters 1. from judge Burnet. Cincinnati 11. Octr. 1843— 2. from Professor O. M Mitchel same date—informing me of the receipt of my Letter of the 3d. and of the Resolution of the Astronomical Society fixing Thursday the 9th. of November, instead of the 7th. as the day, for laying the corner stone of the Observatory. 3. from Thomas H. Sill Burgess of Erie Pennsylvania, enclosing an authenticated copy of a Resolution of the Burgess and Town Council of the borough of Erie, tendering to me the hospitality of the town, and an invitation to me to visit it, dated 14. October. 4. from J. M. Kelley, chairman of a Meeting of Citizens of Cleveland Ohio, and its vicinity, held 14. October, and enclosing copy of a Resolution adopted at that meeting, and inviting me to Cleveland, with a Resolution for the appointment of a Committee of 25 to make suitable arrangements for my reception. 5. from John Newberry. Philadelphia 18 Octr. 1843. asking for an autograph and the age of William Wirt. 6 from William Taylor. 18. Octr 1843. Lee—for an autograph. E. Price Greenleaf was here, and took from the town library some books for others which he returned— John Adams, master of a Cape Cod Coaster came to enquire concerning a claim to be repaid a sum of 90 dollars, levied upon him by the collector at Ocracoke, North Carolina, for omitting to deliver his manifesto— He had sent his claim last winter to the late Mr Burnell, who shortly before his death had written to Captain Adams that he thought there would be little difficulty in recovering the money; but it did not appear that a petition had been presented to the house— I told Captain Adams that if he would have a petition prepared and forwarded to me before the meeting of Congress, together with the document from the collector shewing that he had levied the fine, I would present the petition, and attend to it as far as I may be able— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. I sent up the hill a box of Haut-Brion wine of the old stores from Washington in the central cellar. there remain of these only 3 boxes of Medoc St Julien, and the box from Tain. Time presses upon me like a breaking upon a wheel, and at 11. this evening I brought to a sudden and abrupt termination my astronomical discourse, 54 pages—of which I must select for delivery about one third. It is relief to me inexpressible to have got through— The undertaking was rash and presumptuous. My reputation is now staked upon it; and I pray for the blessing of fortitude to the consummation—

Atmosphere bright— The moon 2 days before her change rose, about E.S.E. as I entered my library. The stars on the three paws of the bear visible Benetnasch pointing directly down; but no appearance of Arcturus.— Weather warm— As the Sun rose the haze of Indian Summer rose with him, and the fire in my library needed no new fuel. My astronomical discourse is finished; and I shiver at the thought of it— Minott Thayer, Asa French, and Mr Fogg of Braintree called on me this morning, and returned to me the copy of the first book of Braintree Records which they borrowed of me, two years since— They have had a copy of it made— The original second book of Braintree Records, they still retain—their copy of it not being yet finished— Mr Thayer enquired what my intention was with regard to the request of the 3 towns that I would write a history of Braintree— I told him that with the best possible intention it would be impossible for me to undertake it while I remain a member of Congress— Mr Thayer is quite discomposed at the prospect of my expedition to Cincinnati, and foresees from it nothing but disaster to myself.— He almost urged me not to go.— I told him that I had perhaps been unwise to undertake and promise it—but it was too late now to reconsider— I must go, happen what may— The Revd. Dr Storrs of Braintree, with his Son a student at the Andover theological institution, paid me a morning visit— He said some enquiries had been made of him whether among the first settlers of Braintree there was a person by the name of Cheseborough. I told him there was and shewed him the name on the record book just returned to me. He also made some enquiries concerning the first Minister of the Mount Wollaston church— Mr Ibrahim Bartlett brought me a Letter from a Lady named Sarah P. Hosford, with a manuscript in folio sheets of Essays in verse and prose, sufficient for a thick octavo volume; upon which in very complimentary verse and prose, she solicits my critical judgment to determine her whether to revise the work for the press or not.— These visits occupied nearly the whole morning.— Charles brought me a whole set of my accounts, which I have now no time to examine. At Sunset I walked up the hill for half an hour. Charles his wife and daughter spent the evening here— I employed all the leisure of the day until close upon midnight in writing an introductory preamble to my proposed address to my constituents, to be delivered next Tuesday at Dedham. The first of the new trials that await me.
Thick fog— Fahrenheit 56.— Clear off. N.E. chill.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from Galatians 5.22. [“]But the fruit of the spirit is love, joy, peace, long suffering, gentleness, goodness, faith.”— The discourse was a commentary—upon the Spirit, as producing the blessings enumerated, one by one in succession, dwelling much upon the spiritual character of Christianity contrasted as it is in the context with the works of the flesh, and of the law, that is the Levitical Law.— This contrast is very remarkably set forth in the chapter from which the text is taken, and towards the close of his sermon, Mr Lunt adverted with great severity to the doctrines which represent the Creator of the universe as a cruel unrelenting tyrant making the race of man not for happiness, but for misery— His text in the afternoon was from 1. Samuel 30.24—“but as his part is, that goeth down to the battle, so shall his part be that tarrieth by the stuff: they shall part alike.” I scarcely know how he brought this text to bear upon the excellence of Christianity; but upon whatever text Mr Lunt preaches, his argument always drifts into that the excellence of Christianity— His mind is copious of details, but not rich in variety of first principles. His sermons are almost always fitted to one frame, like the holy families of the Italian painters— I had counted upon the remnant of this day after meeting to write the peroration of my address at Dedham—as I wrote the exordium last Night. These two parts being all that I can prepare, and these being now excessively hurried— But I was scarcely seated at my table when I was called to two men from Watervil in the State of Maine, named Doolittle and Savage. Their only object was to see me as a curiosity—and they were scarcely gone, when Mr De Grand came in from Boston and spent the Evening with us. He said that the Bank of England was every now and then in trouble—very much embarrassed to make good its payments. That he knew the cause of this, and the remedy; and in an hour’s conversation with Sir Robert Peel could put him in possession of a plan which would avert any such danger forever. He only wanted such an introduction to him as would induce Sir Robert Peel to listen to him one hour, and he could do no other than adopt his plan, and would pay him largely for it— And he asked if I would give him a Letter of introduction to Sir Robert Peel. I answered that my acquaintance with Sir Robert Peel was not sufficient to authorise me to give Letters of introduction to any one— Degrand is crazy.

Cold Northeastern Storm— I went to Boston with my son. I stop’d at Mr Bowditch’s house, and returned the three volumes of Schumachers Astronomische Nachrichten that I had borrowed—then at judge Davis’s to whom I returned Middleton’s Celestial Atlas with the companion, and Croswell’s chart which he had lent me. Dr Morse came in while I was there— Thence I went to Charles’s Office, and immediately after to the probate Office, where I met Mr George Fuller—who had left at Charles’s Office, my statement of account between him as Administrator of Moses Gill, and me as Adiministrator of Thomas Boylston, to which he agreed— I had not yet been able to make the transfer of the 18 shares of Stock of the Pennsylvanian United States Bank, but the judge observed that by paying the balance of 69.48. with a promise to make the transfer which can only be done at Philadelphia, my account might be hereafter settled at the probate office, without needing the further attendance of Mr Fuller— I gave him accordingly, Charles’s check on the merchants Bank for 69.48 at the Merchant’s Bank, and a promise to transfer the shares, and took his receipt in full of settlement, my promise being witnessed by Mr A. C. Spooner.— At Charles’s Office were Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and the two Sons of John Lane Boylston Ward Nicholas and Thomas.— The Trustees signed, and delivered to each of them a Letter offering him the power to occupy, Ward the Estate at Princeton, and Thomas, any part of the Estate at Roxbury, as directed by the Will— Ward desired to make enquiries what was the meaning of the word occupy, and Thomas took time to consider.— The Trustees signed also the Letters, prepared by my Son, to the President and fellows of Harvard University, to the selectmen of Princeton; to John Lane Boylston, and to his three daughters, Alicia, Mary Hallowell, and Louisa Catherine Adams Boylston, Advising each of the bequest to each of them, which took effect on the decease of Mrs Alicia Boylston I then called at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s house and saw Mrs Lawrence and Miss Anna their daughter. He was not at home— They have just returned from their Summer visit to England— At one, from Charles’s Office to Quincy— After dinner, Mr Samuel C. Mann of Dedham came and mentioned that on my way to Dedham to morrow morning a cavalcade escort would meet me at Paul’s bridge— Mr Robinson and Mr Vinson were here— Mr Vinson proposes to keep a school next Summer at Quincy Point.

I was up till near one this morning, preparing for this day, and at half past 4 this morning again up; but the time for action came, and I was not half prepared— I wanted one week more.— At half past seven this morning, with my son, and Mr Brigham I rode to Dedham, and were met by a cavalcade at Paul’s bridge, who escorted us to the house of Mr Sweet— There I received and shook hands with perhaps 200 men and 8 or 10 women from many towns of the congressional district— At 10. a procession was formed under the direction of Major Thomas Adams of Quincy, which wheeled round into the Revd. Dr Burgess’s meeting house, next door to Mr Sweet’s. Mr Copeland, chairman of the Norfolk County Convention’s Committee, read the Resolution of the Convention inviting me to address the whigs of the County— A song, tune of Auld lang Syne, highly complimentary to me was sung, and I delivered my Address of two hours and a half, to a house as crowded as it could hold—a miserable fragment of what it should have been; cut short by my observing the clock, close upon the stroke of one.— I gave Dr Brewer, one of the Editors of the Atlas, the written part of my speech, and he promised a report of the whole in the Atlas, to-morrow. Mr Brigham said he was obliged to stay sometime upon business with the County Committee, and would return home with Mr Bass.— Charles and I with his son John Quincy, who had gone with us returned home to Quincy to dine— After dinner, deacon Spear came with the ultimatum of Josiah Bass junr. 1200 dollars for his two lots of woodland, which I declined accepting, but adhered to my offer of 30 dollars an acre.— He took the two plans.— I planted in the garden and seminary, about 50 Shag bark walnuts, and sundry peach stones and whole pears, in a hurried half hour but was again obliged to abandon all the plantations and transplantations that I had projected— While we were at the round table at tea, Dr George Bancroft came in with Marshal Bertrand and his Son, from Springfield this morning, the marshal assuring me that he had precipitated his journey for the sole purpose of visiting me, having heard that I was to leave home for Cincinnati to morrow— He said he had travelled yesterday, from Albany to Springfield through a thick falling snow all the way. They passed the Evening with us till near ten and I had then only till midnight to finish packing my trunks, and concluded to take Benjamin with me.

Yesterday was one of the most beautiful days of autumn, and was peculiarly favourable to the meeting at Dedham— The weather this morning was not promising; but after a hasty breakfast at a quarter past 5 I came in the Carriage alone to the depot of the Western Rail-road at Boston, which I reached at 10 minutes past 6. Benjamin then took the Carriage to Bigelow’s livery stable in Hawley place, and engaged a man to take the Carriage and horses out to Quincy— While he was gone I saw to the securing our trunks in the baggage waggon and took the keys— Mr Grinnell came soon, and Mrs Grinnell was with him. Mr Stearns of Springfield accosted me, and said he had come to Boston to escort me to Springfield— At 7. the Cars started from the depot, and at half past 9. we reached Worcester Mr Dalton the husband of Mrs Grinnell’s sister came also with us. Mr Morris judge of probate for the county of Hamden joined us— After we had passed Worcester, Mr Joshua Leavitt came into the Car in which we had taken our seats, and left us at West Brookfield.— He had left Boston with us in the same train but another Car— He read to me from a newspaper slip, Wise’s Letter to the party which gave a public dinner to Robert Mercer Taliaferro Hunter— We reached Springfield soon after noon and were visited by Mr William B. Calhoun, Mr John B Kirkham, and sundry others among whom a Mr Bliss of Wilbraham, a person rather eccentric in his conversation, but very kind in his disposition who said he had come 12 miles from Wilbraham purposely to see me— Mr Morris was also warmly complimentary in his expressions of respect for my character We took lodging at Warriner’s Hotel one of the best in the United States. He gave me an excellent bed chamber with a fire— We dined at 2. and after dinner I was so worn down with weariness, three almost sleepless Nights, and anxiety that my faculties seemed benumbed and I felt as if falling into a lethargy. I retired to my chamber, threw myself on a bed and had two hours of refreshing sleep— Coll. Howard had been one of the first persons to greet us on our arrival— We took tea at his house.— His family consists of two daughters both invalids, one particularly in appearance healthy and handsome, but threatened with blindness.— At half past six we repaired to a meeting house, and I read my Lecture on Society and civilization—from a Stage in front of the pulpit, before a table with four wax candles— I read the manuscript with great difficulty and frequent hesitation— A crowded house, and listening auditory, an hour and a half.

I rose before 4. O’Clock, in good health except inflamed eyes strained by the labour of last evening, and I had 3 hours for writing before Sunrise—invaluable time to me for saving the diary from running into long arrears— After breakfast I called with Mr Grinnell at a Book-sellers shop and purchased Goodrich’s North American Tourist, and Mitchell’s Travellers Guide through the United States. We had sundry visitors whose names it is impossible for me to remember, but among them was Mr William Allen author of an American biographical dictionary, from whom I had recently received a Letter of enquiry concerning the creed of my father, and which is unanswered— He reminded me of it, and I had forgotten it altogether: but recollected it distinctly when he mentioned it— Coll. Howard came with his Carriage and took Mr Grinnell Mr George Bliss and me over to West-Springfield, where there was to be an annual Cattle-show. The people were collecting; but the show was to be at noon, and we could not wait. Mr Samuel Lathrop’s house was shewn to me, but it was said he was an invalid and could not be seen.— We returned to Warriner’s took an early dinner and at a quarter before one, with Mr Grinnell and Benjamin I repaired to the train of the Western Rail-road Cars and took our Seats for Albany—leaving Mrs Grinnell and Mr Dalton to depart a quarter of an hour later for Boston. We reached Greenbush as the Clock in Albany was striking six— The distance is one hundred miles Before the railway traveling, the journey from Boston to Albany occupied two days and a half. It is now daily performed from 7. in the morning to 6 in the Evening. But the work on this road which cost about ten millions of dollars and was completed in six years is much greater than the pyramids of Egypt or the wall of China— About 15 miles west of Springfield, there is a stream branching out from Westfield river called thewinding along the precipitous rocks, and over which in the space of a mile eleven bridges have been cast—one of them where the excavation was 70 feet deep, caved in last Monday, and made a breach which has been temporarily repaired with timber, and over which the passage is not without danger— In passing the Hudson, at Greenbush, Mercy saved me from a broken leg or neck. At Albany I met Josiah Quincy junr and Mr Crawford; and was visited by the New-York Senators, and Lt. Governor Dickenson and D. D. Barnard.

In crossing the river last evening, I felt as if I was incrusted in a bed of snow— The sun had peered out just before going down, but set in a cloud.— We lodged at Congress hall, where I was surprized to meet Mr Josiah Quincy junr and a young Englishman named Crawford, who two days before had been introduced to me at Dedham— The Lieutenant Governor and Senate of New-York are in Session as the Supreme Court of Errors and most of them were lodging at Congress Hall— As was the U.S. District judge Conklin whom I met in the entry, and who told me he had been holding a court.— When I awoke this morning I heard a rattling of hail against the windows of my bed chamber, which continued and turned to snow. I wrote till half past 6. when I sallied out to the barber’s shop adjoining the hall and was shaved.— As I was putting on my coat after coming out of the hands of the shaver, another man who was sitting on the anxious stool, looking at me, says, who is that Stranger? said I, my name is John Quincy Adams, if you ever heard it before.— I thought so, said he—starting up, with his face covered with lath; came and shook hands with me, and said his name was Weeks— At 7. O’Clock we breakfasted, and at 8 were driven in a cab omnibus to the train of western cars, which were frozen to the ground so that it took half an hour of hard tugging, and scourging of horses to get them loose— Another half hour was lost in raising to its operative point the steam of the loco-motive, and the snow falling incessantly on the rail made it so slippery that great care was necessary to guard the wheels from slipping off the rail. The snow continued inexorably till we arrived at Utica, nearly two hours belated. Precisely such an accident had happened to me on the 1st of Decr 1841. when I first attempted the Western rail-road from Boston to the Hudson river.— I did not expect it on the 27th of October, but Marshal Bertrand had it last Monday the 23d.— And there was a snow storm which covered the ground on the 18th. My only resource this day was to adhere to my seat in the car, the whole way to Utica, with the windows closed, passing through Schenectady Amsterdam, Little falls and Herkimer, and the whole valley of the Mohawk as if in the dead of Night—at Utica, I found Charles Adams Johnson at the depot; but his brother William had gone on before to join us at Geneva— We had but a half an hour to dine at Utica, during which Mr Alexander B. Johnson came to bid us welcome and farewell— We started from Utica, just before sunset and reached Syracuse at half past 9 in the evening. The cars proceeded this evening to Auburnmiles further, but we had our trunks taken out of the baggage waggon and took our lodging for the night here to take the morning train to-morrow.— Mr J. P. B. Storer paid me an evening visit—

I wrote this morning from 5 to 1/2 past 7.— The day was fine and from 8. A.M—till past midnight, we past it in the rail way Cars— I take the list down of the places which we passed through, from Albany to Buffalo with the distances, as follows from

There is no uniformity in human more monotonous than that of traveling in rail-road Cars.— We traversed this day 180 miles of one of the most beautiful Countries in the world, presenting at this moment a dreary and desolate aspect like Nova Zembla in January one white sheet of snow covering two thirds of the way, and bare ground the remainder—interspersed with Orchards loaded with apples. It was the same country through which I had passed last July, with so many flattering testimonials of kindness and regard by the inhabitants— My passage now is silent and unnoticed— It is known only to Mr Johnson of Utica and his family that I am upon this road— At Geneva we found William Clarkson Johnson waiting for us, and he came on with us. At Auburn, Canandaigua, and Rochester we met persons whom we had seen in the Summer but whose names all slip from my memory, excepting Gideon Granger son of Francis at Canandaigua. The father is at New-York— During the short half hour for changing cars at Auburn, a gentleman went to give notice to Mr William H Seward that I was there, but he was not at home. We reached Rochester just before 5. p.m. and had half an hour to go to the hotel, dine and return to the cars. We had yet 80 miles to travel, and night was coming on. At Batavia, where the platform broke down when we passed through before, there was solitude now—but the keeper of the house Mr Hall remembered me, and introduced to me his sister and his daughter— Of fellow travellers we had many changes through the day— Several of them recognized and conversed with me; but left no trace of themselves on my memory except the President of Geneva College, and I do not remember his name— At every station where the cars stop for wood and water, there is a large table spread with hot tea and coffee, bread and butter cakes, puddings and pies, of which any passenger may partake at his option for a cent or a dollar. From the rail-road depot at Buffalo to the American hotel we came in a double cab— At a quarter before one Sunday morning they gave me a small bed-chamber for the night, and at two I was in bed.

The room in which I slept was so small, so cold and so dark, that they gave me another this morning, very comfortable, the same in which I had slept last July. Immediately after breakfast, Mr Thompson, Dr John’s and Mr Dobbins called on me, and informed me, that they together with Mr Hunter and General Charles M Read, member of Congress elect from the Eri District of Pennsylvania, had been appointed a Committee by the inhabitants of the borough to invite me to visit them on my way to Cincinnati—which invitation I accepted and it was agreed that we should embark at 8. O’Clock to morrow morning in the Steamer Genl. Wayne in which those gentlemen had come down to meet me— Mr Fillmore immediately after came in and invited us to tea at his house this evening, and offered us seats in his pew at the unitarian church which we accepted. The preacher was Mr Hosmer and his text was from Matthew 6.31. “What shall we eat? or, What shall we drink? Or, wherewithal shall we be clothed?” He left out the preceding words of the verse [“]Therefore, take no thought saying” so that the Sermon was not directly upon the negative precept, but upon the anxious cravings of mankind for the supply of these wants incident to their physical nature— The discourse was an earnest and affectionate exhortation to the auditory not to indulge this excessing anxiety for the necessaries of life, but to guard against them by industry moderation and frugality and most especially by suppressing their propensities to lavish and extravagant expense, which he denounced as the besetting sin of the age and especially of the place.— An excellent and eminently practical Sermon.— Mr Hosmer gave notice that the anniversary festival of the protestant reformation would be held this evening. I observed that the usage of the worshipers here is to be seated during prayer, and to stand at the singing of the hymns. They use the compilation of the late Dr Greenwood— We dined at the Hotel and by invitation of Mr Rogers attended the evening service of the episcopal church: where a stranger, read prayers for the 20th Sunday after Trinity and Mr Hawkes, the settled minister was the preacher— His text and his sermon have slipped from my memory, which is the fault not of his mediocrity, but of my lethargy. Mr Hawkes is a young man, a brother of the celebrated Dr Hawkes; and married a sister of Mrs Edward Stanly. Returning from church I met in the street my old friend Albert H. Tracy, and was visited at the hotel by Lieutt. Williams the engineer, and others— We attended a tea and evening party at Mr Fillmore’s— Mr Love having insisted that I should first stop in at his house where his eldest daughter sung and played on the Piano the old armed Chair— Conversation with Tracy—

div.dateline: Buffalo. Monday 30. October. Lake Erie Point Abino.
div.p: I wrote this morning till near breakfast time— No one can imagine the labour of my hands to keep this diary up with the current of time— It requires an average of two hours every day, and in the ordinary current of business at home, I have no difficulty in fixing the time—the hours before breakfast are always disposable, though not always applied. We embarked this morning before 8. in the Steamer Genl.
